Graphical abstract Semi-hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream is an industrially important process. Recent work on the purification of ethylene mainly focuses on the modification of Pd catalysts; little attention has been paid to the development of alternative catalysts with low-cost metals. Herein, a series of Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts, with varied Ni/Ag atomic ratios, were prepared by wetness co-impregnation method. Their activity for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream was evaluated, which showed that the introduction of Ag decreased the formation of both ethane and methane, thus increased the ethylene selectivity. The ethylene selectivity over the AgNi0.25/SiO2 catalyst was increased by >600% when compared with the corresponding monometallic Ni0.25/SiO2 as well as the simple physical mixture of the monometallic Ag/SiO2 and Ni0.25/SiO2 catalysts. As was verified by a combination of the X-ray diffraction, high angular annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy under scanning transmission electron microscopy results, decreased Ni content induced the sintering of the bimetallic nanoparticles while with uniform dispersion. Temperature-programmed reduction results demonstrated that, compared with the corresponding monometallic catalysts, both the reduction of AgOx and NiOx were promoted in the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts. In-situ Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy results also illustrated obvious interaction between Ag and Ni. The contact between Ag and Ni may account for the enhanced ethylene selectivity. Keywords Ni Ag Acetylene Selective hydrogenation Excess ethylene 1 Introduction Ethylene is one of the most important products of the petrochemical industry; it always comes from the pyrolysis of hydrocarbons, such as cracking of naphtha and ethane [1–3]. Among this process, small amount of acetylene is one of the most undesired by-products, which is poisonous to the polymerization catalysts and must be diminished to meet an acceptable level [4–6]. The most preferred method to remove acetylene is selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene, which will be beneficial to lowering the content of acetylene and increasing the amount of ethylene. Traditionally, Pd-based catalysts are chosen for this process for their high acetylene conversion; however the selectivity to ethylene is low [7–9]. To improve the selectivity to ethylene, another element (Au, Ag, Cu, Ga, Si, Zn, C, S, etc.) is always introduced to Pd [10–20]. Group IB metals (Au, Ag, Cu) are among the most widely studied partner of Pd [10–12,20–27], especially for Cu and Ag. For example, Anderson et al. did a lot of work on Cu-Pd bimetallic catalysts for the semi-hydrogenation of acetylene [21–24]. While Ag modified Pd catalysts are widely used under an ethylene rich-stream, and have long been recognized as the preferred choice in industry [1,3,11]. Our previous work also demonstrated that Ag alloyed Pd single-atom catalyst is efficient and durable for the semi-hydrogenation of acetylene in excess ethylene [25]. As the commercially used catalyst, Pd is identified as the active element for this reaction, but it is one of the noble metals with high price. Besides lowering the concentration and making efficient use of Pd atoms, a cost-effective way is to substitute Pd with another low-cost metal to achieve satisfactory catalytic performance. As another element in the same group of VIII as Pd, nickel showed high activity for a series of hydrogenation reactions due to the relatively low barrier for hydrogen dissociation [28–32]. It has also been identified as an active element for alkyne hydrogenation in industry [29]. Similar to Pd, though with high acetylene conversion, the monometallic Ni catalyst displays poor selectivity to ethylene for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene, the modification of other elements will tune both the activity and selectivity simultaneously [33–35]. For example, by screening a series of less expensive bimetallic compounds, Studt et al. identified that, compared with the monometallic Ni catalyst, NiZn alloy supported on MgAl2O4 spinel exhibited much higher selectivity to ethylene at low pressures, and the catalytic performance would surpass that of the Ag-Pd system [35]. Pérez-Ramírez et al. did a lot of work on alkyne hydrogenation [36–38], they found that the ternary system (Cu-Ni-Fe) with appropriate metal ratios displayed outstanding ethylene selectivity, while the reaction was under pure acetylene and H2 conditions. Moreover, compared with the Pd-based catalysts, high operating temperatures (523K, etc.) were needed for this process [36]. The DFT results from Yang et al. demonstrated that, compared with pure Ni, the ethylene selectivity was improved through the formation of the bimetallic surfaces of Au/Ni(111) and Ag/Ni(111) [39]. Despite of the above mentioned efforts to seek for the low-cost catalysts, little attention has been paid to the design of novel alternative catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream. Especially for the possibility of the replacement of the commercially recognized Ag-Pd system with Ag-Ni bimetallic catalyst, to the best of our knowledge, till now there are few reports on this catalyst being used in this process. Herein, aimed at the investigation of the substitution of Ni for Pd and the effect of Ag on the Ni catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream, we prepared a series of silica gel supported Ag-Ni bimetallic catalysts by employing simple incipient wetness co-impregnation method. Their catalytic performance for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene in excess ethylene was investigated. Combined with the characterization results of XRD, HAADF-STEM, STEM-EDS, their geometric structure was analyzed. The interaction between Ag and Ni was further verified by TPR, in-situ FT-IR. Thus, the relationship between the catalytic performance and the structure of the catalysts was clarified. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of catalysts with different Ni:Ag atomic ratios were prepared by incipient wetness co-impregnation. First, silica gel (Qingdao Ocean Chemical Plant with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 463m2 g−1) was impregnated with a mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and AgNO3 solutions to obtain a nominal Ag loading of 5wt% and different Ni:Ag atomic ratios. The samples were subsequently dried at 80°C for 10h, followed by calcination in air at 400°C for 2h. The as-prepared catalysts are denoted as AgNix/SiO2, with x denoting the Ni:Ag atomic ratio. To make a comparison with the corresponding monometallic Ni catalyst, Ni0.25/SiO2 and Ni1/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by the same method, with the similar Ni contents to the AgNi0.25/SiO2 and AgNi1/SiO2 catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The actual metal loadings of all the as-prepared catalysts were quantified by inductively coupled plasma spectrometry (ICP-AES) on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid II XSP instrument. The results were shown in Table 1 . X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a PW3040/60 X’ Pert Pro Super (PANalytical) diffractometer, operating at 40kV and 40mA using a Cu Kα radiation source (λ=0.15432nm). The scanning angle (2θ) was from 10° to 80°. High angular annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained on a JEM-2100F instrument equipped with STEM dark-field (DF) detector operating at 200kV. Elemental distribution of the catalysts was analyzed by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) under scanning TEM (STEM) mode. Prior to observation, a small amount of the reduced (at 400°C) catalysts was ultrasonically dispersed by ethanol, and several drops of the suspension placed on copper microgrid covered with carbon polymer, then dried at room temperature. The particle size distributions of as-prepared catalysts were collected by measuring more than 200 particles from different areas. Elemental distribution analysis was undertaken over relatively large particles. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 automated characterization system. First, about 100mg of the calcined sample was loaded into a U-shaped quartz reactor and pretreated with air at 150°C for 30min to remove the adsorbed water. After cooling to 50°C, the flowing gas was switched to 10vol% H2/Ar, and the catalyst was heated to 500°C at 10°Cmin−1. Fourier-Transform Infrared Spectra (FT-IR) were carried out on a Bruker EQUINOX 55 infrared spectrometer with a DTGS detector. Prior to the CO chemisorption, the as-prepared samples were reduced at 400°C under flowing 80vol% H2/He (20mLmin−1) for 1h, followed by evacuation at 400°C for 0.5h, then cooled to room temperature. An initial background spectrum was collected before the introduction of CO to the surface of the sample, and subtracted automatically from subsequent spectra. CO adsorption experiments were undertaken sequentially. After introduction of the similar amount of CO and followed by evacuation for 5min, the spectra were collected. 2.3 Activity test Selective hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream was carried out in a quartz reactor. Prior to the activity tests, 30mg of catalysts were reduced under flowing 80vol% H2/He (20mLmin−1) at 400°C for 1h followed by purging with He (20mLmin−1) at the same temperature. After cooling to room temperature, a gas mixture with 1.0vol% C2H2, 20.0vol% H2 and 20.0vol% C2H4 balanced with He was introduced into the reactor. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 60, 000mLgas gcatalyst −1 h−1. With the feed gas purities of H2 (UHP, 99.999%), He (UHP, 99.999%), C2H2 and C2H4 (mixture of 4.76vol.% C2H2 in C2H4, with the impurity of about 50ppm amount of C2H6 and 10ppm amount of CH4 from Dalian Special Gases Co., LTD.). Mass flow controllers were used to control all gas flows. The temperature was held constant for 25min before ramping to the next temperature point. We checked that the conversion/selectivity could reach steady state within 25min. Both the inlet and outlet gas composition were analyzed by on-line gas chromatography (Agilent Technologies 6890N) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). As C2H4 and C2H6 were the only C2 products detected by GC, accompanied by ppm amount of CH4. Negligible oligomers were formed during the hydrogenation process, due to the large excess of hydrogen in the feed gas [22–24] and the short contact time. Thus, based on the inlet and outlet volume concentrations of the feed gas and products, the conversion and selectivity were calculated as follows: (1) C 2 H 2 c o n v e r s i o n = [ C 2 H 2 ] i n − [ C 2 H 2 ] o u t [ C 2 H 2 ] i n × 100 % (2) C 2 H 4 s e l e c t i v i t y = ( 1 − ( [ C H 4 ] o u t − [ C H 4 ] i n ) /2 + [ C 2 H 6 ] o u t − [ C 2 H 6 ] i n [ C 2 H 2 ] i n − [ C 2 H 2 ] o u t ) × 100 % (3) C H 4 s e l e c t i v i t y = ( ( [ C H 4 ] o u t − [ C H 4 ] i n ) /2 [ C 2 H 2 ] i n − [ C 2 H 2 ] o u t ) × 100 % With [CxHy]in and [CxHy]out denoted the volume concentrations determined by the GC for the inlet and outlet CxHy, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance We primarily employed the simulated front-end conditions, that is, with both high concentration of ethylene and hydrogen contained in the feed gas [1–3]. The monometallic Ni0.25/SiO2 catalyst displayed high acetylene conversion at low temperatures. Almost complete acetylene conversion could be achieved at 120°C (Fig. 1 a), while its selectivity to ethylene was below −1100% (Fig. 1b), indicating that a large amount of ethylene in the feedstock was hydrogenated to ethane, leading to a waste of the feed gas. The monometallic Ag/SiO2 catalyst showed negligible activity even at high temperatures (Fig. 1a). This is different from the work of Vilé et al. [37], which showed that Ag particles were active for propyne hydrogenation. The difference could be ascribed to the different feedstocks or active sites. With the introduction of Ni, the acetylene conversion over the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts increased obviously, almost complete acetylene conversion could be achieved over the AgNi0.5/SiO2 and AgNi1/SiO2 catalysts at 160°C, with the corresponding extremely low selectivity to ethylene between −400% and ∼−800%. The AgNi0.25/SiO2 bimetallic catalyst, displayed 98.0% acetylene conversion at 160°C, with improved ethylene selectivity by >600% in contrast to that of the corresponding monometallic Ni0.25/SiO2 catalyst. With further decreased Ni content, the AgNi0.125/SiO2 catalyst displayed 31.4% selectivity to ethylene at 160°C, but with the decreased acetylene conversion to 90.4%. The ethylene selectivity increased when the temperature increased from 160 to 200°C, which may be due to the high desorption rates of the produced ethylene at high temperatures, thus its further hydrogenation to ethane was avoided [20,25,40]. The catalytic performance of the monometallic Ni/SiO2 catalyst is similar to that of the monometallic Pd/SiO2 catalyst, with high acetylene conversion but extremely low selectivity to ethylene [41–43]. The enhanced ethylene selectivity over the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts with decreasing Ni contents is similar to most of the Pd-based bimetallic catalysts [44–46]. Different from the Pd-based catalysts, besides the main by-product of ethane, a small amount of methane was also detected at relatively high temperatures. The monometallic Ni0.25/SiO2 catalyst showed the highest methane selectivity of ∼3% (Fig. 1c). While the methane selectivity over the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts was negligible. That is to say, compared with the monometallic Ni/SiO2 catalyst, the introduction of Ag could reduce the formation of both ethane and methane (Fig. 1b and c), corresponding to the enhanced selectivity to ethylene. The change of the ethylene selectivity with the increased acetylene conversion could be clearly seen in Fig. 2 . Over the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts, the ethylene selectivity decreased as the acetylene conversion increased to 100%, the AgNi0.125/SiO2 catalyst with low Ni content can achieve both high conversion and relatively high ethylene selectivity. To make comparison of the catalytic performances of the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts with different Ni:Ag atomic ratios, the catalytic results of the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts at the reaction temperature of 160°C were summarized in Fig. 3 . With high Ni loadings, though complete acetylene conversion could be attained, the selectivity to ethylene was extremely low, that is, large amount of ethylene was hydrogenated to ethane. With the decreased loading of Ni, the ethylene selectivity increased obviously, from lower than −800% to 31.4%. The simple physical mixture of the monometallic Ag/SiO2 and Ni0.25/SiO2 catalyst was also evaluated for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream. As compared in Fig. 1, its catalytic performance was similar to that of the monometallic Ni0.25/SiO2 catalyst, with high acetylene conversion but extremely low selectivity to ethylene. Both the ethylene selectivity was much lower than that of the AgNi0.25/SiO2 catalyst that prepared by incipient wetness co-impregnation method, indicating interaction between Ag and Ni was needed for the enhanced ethylene selectivity. Thus, in the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts, the synergetic effect might be originated from the interaction between Ag and Ni. Further investigations on the structure of the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts will be discussed in the following sections. 3.2 Particle size To find out the reasons for the enhanced ethylene selectivity, the structure of the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts and the corresponding monometallic Ag/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2 catalysts were analyzed. Firstly, XRD was undertaken over all the samples. As shown in Fig. 4 A, after calcination there was no diffraction peak of AgOx or NiOx could be detected over the monometallic Ag/SiO2 and Ni0.25/SiO2 catalysts, which may be attributed to the amorphous state or small size of the nanoparticles. In terms of the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts, the diffraction peaks for NiOx appeared, indicating increased size of the NiOx nanoparticles, which could be ascribed to the increased loadings of Ni. After reduction at 400°C (Fig. 4B), there was still no diffraction peak could be detected over the monometallic Ag/SiO2 and Ni0.25/SiO2 catalysts. While both Ag and Ni diffraction peaks could be detected over the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts. With the increased loadings of Ni, the peak for Ag became much more obvious, indicating the addition of Ni induced the sintering of the Ag nanoparticles. This trend is similar to our previously reported Ag-Pd/SiO2 system [25], indicating interaction occurred between Ag and Ni after reduction pretreatment. In order to get insight into the difference of the size distribution of the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic nanoparticles, the reduced samples of the AgNi0.5/SiO2 and AgNi0.25/SiO2 catalysts were subsequently characterized by the HAADF-STEM. As shown in Fig. 5 , the average particle sizes of the AgNi0.5/SiO2 and AgNi0.25/SiO2 catalysts were 2.6 and 4.8nm, respectively. Both the particle sizes were larger than that of the monometallic Ag/SiO2 catalysts (∼2.5nm) [25], consistent with the XRD results that the addition of Ni to Ag promoted the sintering of the nanoparticles. Moreover, from the diagram of the size distribution, we can see that, though with larger average particle size, the size distribution of the AgNi0.25/SiO2 catalyst was more uniform than that of the AgNi0.5/SiO2 catalyst, indicating decreased loadings of Ni will induce uniform dispersion of the bimetallic particles. This result is consistent with the XRD result, illustrating the geometric effect between Ag and Ni. To detect the elemental distribution in the bimetallic particles, STEM-EDS analysis was undertaken over the reduced AgNi0.5/SiO2 and AgNi0.25/SiO2 catalysts, the results were shown in Fig. 6 . We can see in Fig. 6a, over the AgNi0.5/SiO2 catalyst, with relatively high Ni loading, Ni and Ag were not so evenly distributed in the particles, we found only Ni or Ag contained in part of the particle. In terms of the AgNi0.25/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 6b), both Ni and Ag could be detected in the relatively large particles, indicating the decreased Ni amounts could make even mixture of the two elements. This was also consistent with the phase diagram and the results in the literature that it is hard for the formation of Ag-Ni alloy, only small amount of Ni could be alloyed with Ag [47,48]. This may be one of the main reasons for the catalytic performance of the Ag-Ni/SiO2 catalysts with high Ni loadings alike that of the monometallic Ni/SiO2 catalyst. 3.3 Reducibility TPR profiles of all the calcined samples are displayed in Fig. 7 . Consistent with our previous report [25], the monometallic Ag/SiO2 catalyst demonstrated one reduction feature around 100°C, which may be ascribed to the reduction of AgOx [49,50]. The monometallic Ni1/SiO2 catalyst displayed one broad reduction feature from 300 to 550°C, which is the result of the reduction of multiple NiOx species [51]. The reduction temperature is lower than the unsupported pure NiO [52], which could be ascribed to the NiOx with small particle sizes and/or their weak interaction with the silica support [53]. The Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts exhibited two reduction features around 90 and 350°C, respectively. The former could be attributed to the reduction of AgOx, and the latter was ascribed to the reduction of NiOx. Compared with the corresponding monometallic Ag/SiO2 and Ni1/SiO2 catalysts, both the reduction features of AgOx and NiOx shifted to lower temperatures obviously, especially for the NiOx, the reduction temperature decreased from 550°C to 400°C. This indicated that after the introduction of Ag, the interaction between the NiOx and silica was disturbed, which may be ascribed to the preferential interaction of NiOx with Ag other than silica. All these illustrated the interaction between Ag and Ni, which promoted the reduction of both AgOx and NiOx. 3.4 In-situ FT-IR The existed states of nickel can be distinguished by the adsorption of CO [54]. Thus the evolution of its surface states was probed by employing in-situ FT-IR coupled with CO adsorption. The results are shown in Fig. 8 , we can see that there was no obvious adsorption band existed over the monometallic Ni1/SiO2 catalyst; this may be attributed to the incomplete reduction of NiOx. According to the TPR profile in Fig. 7, after reduction at 400°C, only part of NiOx could be reduced over the monometallic Ni1/SiO2 catalyst. In accordance with our previous report, the monometallic Ag/SiO2 catalyst displayed weak adsorption band of CO around 2170cm−1, which could be ascribed to the adsorption of CO on Agx+ sites [25,55]. The formation of Ag-Ni bimetallic catalyst promoted the reduction of both AgOx and NiOx, thus the FT-IR result for AgNi1/SiO2 catalyst with high Ni loading showed strong CO adsorption band in the region of 2000–2050cm−1 and 1850–1900cm−1, the former could be assigned to the linearly adsorbed CO on Ni surface and the latter was attributed to the bridging adsorption of CO on Ni atoms [56,57]. While in terms of the AgNi0.25/SiO2 catalyst, with relatively low content of Ni, bridging adsorption of CO disappeared, which is resulted from the geometric effect between Ag and Ni [56,57], inducing different dispersion of Ni in these two catalysts. This result was also consistent with our STEM-EDS results, indicating the dispersion of Ni in the bimetallic nanoparticles can be tuned by different Ni loadings. For another way, compared with the AgNi1/SiO2 catalyst, the linearly adsorbed bands shifted from 2046cm−1 to 2053cm−1 and 2003cm−1 to 1997cm−1, respectively. In accordance with the reported data [57,58], demonstrating that electron transfer might occur between Ag and Ni. 3.5 Relationship between performance and structure According to the above results, we can summarize the relationship between the structure of the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts and their catalytic performances. Over the monometallic Ni/SiO2 catalyst, high acetylene conversion was accompanied by extremely low selectivity to ethylene. As to the Ag-Ni bimetallic catalysts, when the loading of Ni is relatively high (e.g., Ni/Ag=1), it displayed extremely low ethylene selectivity for semi-hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream (Fig. 1b), alike that of the monometallic Ni0.25/SiO2 catalyst and the physical mixture of the monometallic Ni0.25/SiO2 and Ag/SiO2 catalysts. Because it is hard for the Ag and Ni to form alloy, there might be separated monometallic Ni nanoparticles in the AgNi1/SiO2 catalyst. With the decreasing of the Ni/Ag atomic ratios, the ethylene selectivity was greatly promoted. From the characterization results of the HAADF-STEM, TPR and FT-IR, we could know that there was interaction between Ag and Ni, which contributed to the enhanced ethylene selectivity. That is, in the bimetallic Ag-Ni catalysts, not all of the Ag and Ni interacted closely. Thus, the catalytic performances of the Ag-Ni bimetallic catalysts highly depended on the Ni/Ag atomic ratio, which could greatly influence the extent of the interaction between Ni and Ag. Accordingly, we illustrated the relationship between the structure of the Ag-Ni nanoparticles and the catalytic performances in Fig. 9 . Over the catalysts with relatively high Ni content (e.g., the Ni/Ag atomic ratio≥0.5), it may display the catalytic performance alike that of the monometallic Ni/SiO2 catalyst, due to the existence of separated monometallic Ni nanoparticles. For the catalysts with low Ni content (e.g., the Ni/Ag atomic ratio≤0.25), it displayed relatively high ethylene selectivity, because most of the Ni interacted closely with the Ag. It is confirmed that there was geometric effect between Ni and Ag in the bimetallic catalysts. However, it is hard to determine the exact electron transfer occurred between Ag and Ni in our catalysts, as can be seen from the STEM-EDS result of the AgNi1/SiO2 catalyst with high Ni loading, Ni and Ag could hardly interact with each other, therefore its catalytic performance was similar to that of the monometallic Ni/SiO2 catalyst. In the AgNi0.25/SiO2 catalyst, the Ni content was too low to be detected by techniques such as XPS, etc. However, as the electronegativity of Ag is slightly different from that of Ni, we could make the hypothesis that the electron would probably transfer from Ag to Ni. This is consistent with our FT-IR results, thus inducing negatively charged Ni. It has been reported that, negatively charged Ni could be propitious to the enhanced ethylene selectivity due to the weak adsorption of the produced ethylene [59,60]. Combined with the XRD, HAADF-STEM, TPR and FT-IR results, we could get the point that both the geometric and electronic effects between Ag and Ni may contribute to the enhanced catalytic performance of the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts. However, to discriminate the contribution of the geometric and electronic effects may be a complex process. From our characterization results, we can see that the geometric effect was much more obvious than the electronic effect. Thus in our system, the geometric effect may contribute more to the better catalytic performance than the electronic effect does, that is, the dispersion of Ni may affect the selectivity to ethylene in priority. 4 Conclusion By using incipient wetness co-impregnation method, a series of Ag-Ni/SiO2 catalysts were synthesized. The monometallic Ni/SiO2 catalyst displayed high acetylene conversion for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream, while its selectivity to ethylene was extremely low. In contrast, the Ag-Ni bimetallic catalysts could improve the selectivity to ethylene by >600%. Decreased Ni contents induced the sintering of the bimetallic nanoparticles while with uniform dispersion. The interaction between Ag and Ni contributed to the enhanced catalytic performance. Although small amount of ethylene in the feedstock will be hydrogenated to ethane at complete acetylene conversion, due to the low cost and high activity of Ni, it will be one of the promising alternatives to the Pd-based catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream. coredata.dc:description: Semi-hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream is an industrially important process. Recent work on the purification of ethylene mainly focuses on the modification of Pd catalysts; little attention has been paid to the development of alternative catalysts with low-cost metals. Herein, a series of Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts, with varied Ni/Ag atomic ratios, were prepared by wetness co-impregnation method. Their activity for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream was evaluated, which showed that the introduction of Ag decreased the formation of both ethane and methane, thus increased the ethylene selectivity. The ethylene selectivity over the AgNi0.25/SiO2 catalyst was increased by >600% when compared with the corresponding monometallic Ni0.25/SiO2 as well as the simple physical mixture of the monometallic Ag/SiO2 and Ni0.25/SiO2 catalysts. As was verified by a combination of the X-ray diffraction, high angular annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy under scanning transmission electron microscopy results, decreased Ni content induced the sintering of the bimetallic nanoparticles while with uniform dispersion. Temperature-programmed reduction results demonstrated that, compared with the corresponding monometallic catalysts, both the reduction of AgOx and NiOx were promoted in the Ag-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts. In-situ Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy results also illustrated obvious interaction between Ag and Ni. The contact between Ag and Ni may account for the enhanced ethylene selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrogenation of acetylene in an ethylene-rich stream over silica supported Ag-Ni bimetallic catalysts
